answers.answer: Thanks man but my exposure was a needle stick...not oral. I appreciate you taking the time to post this up...
heck..you didn't read the first one... thats for you...6 week is good enough. 3 months neg is waaayy tooo conclusive...you get that?

question: Source:  http://www.aac.org/site/PageServer?pagename=basics_homeQ) Why do some sources advise waiting longer than 6 weeks for HIV testing?A) Most people will test accurately for HIV after 6 weeks have passed since their last risk. In very rare cases where a person has a highly compromised immune system, such as those in which a person has recently undergone chemotherapy or an organ transplant, it may take 3-6 months for their body to develop enough antibodies to test positive. These are very extreme situations, however, and other more common conditions such as colds or the flu, diabetes, asthma, and many others, will not affect the body's development of HIV antibodies in that way. Those who suggest window periods longer than 6 weeks are trying to account for all those who may also have compromised immune systems.2)  Receiving Oral SexSince HIV is not transmitted by saliva, there is generally no risk if you are receiving oral sex (unless there is a lot of blood in their mouth).SO all the -ve's beyond six week mark, feel confident...
